text: hi I'm Brooke partridge and I run final
wave consulting were a strategy
consulting firm focused on helping
technology companies grow their revenue
in emerging markets we have grown really
quickly in 2008 and we were prepared for
more growth when the bottom of the
economy fell out and at that point we
had gotten to a structure where smaller
projects were really a lot less
profitable for us to do in fact a lot of
small projects were unprofitable and yet
those were the only contracts that were
coming through at that point smaller
projects and we had to figure out a way
to survive the economic crisis and do
our business differently being
profitable on a lot less revenue and
smaller contract sizes job number one
was to cut operating costs and like
everyone else it was inevitable for us
to do layoffs we cut deep and fast and
projected that the market was not going
to turn around for at least a year I
think most small businesses tend to hire
people that they know and they trust and
that usually means that personal
relationships come along with those
employees so in my case I ended up
laying off three long term friends the
employees that were left also took a
large pay cut and and then we made some
dramatic cuts in our overall operating
costs we reduced all of our expenses by
twenty to thirty percent we have to
travel to some degree of see clients but
that was the only travel that we had
everything else was done virtually
another big step we made because we're a
global organization and were spread
pretty thinly around the world we were
able to get rid of our physical office
space and switch to a model of sort of
daily rental space for offices and it's
turned out to work extremely well for us
we can go anywhere
world with this company that we've
chosen and have really professional
office space on any given day when we
need it and it's actually cut our
operating costs by three quarters in
terms of our office expenses of course
we had to hunker down and close as much
business as humanly possible we took in
any kind of project we could close of
any size because the smaller contracts
did add up and allowed us to to survive
but most importantly we changed our
operating model so of course we had
operations people and people focused on
activities that were more overhead as
opposed to contributing directly to
projects previous to the economic crisis
and that all changed we had to rethink
everybody's role and everyone was
contributing to projects so that they
became a variable costs instead of an
overhead costs and that helped a lot in
terms of keeping more of the money
inside the business rather than having
to contract out parts of our project
execution one of the less tangible
challenges during the economic crisis
has been maintaining employee morale job
number one after the layoffs was to
psychologically rehire all the people
that were left to make sure they had a
sense of purpose and hope that that we
had a plan for getting through this
difficult time and to bring spirits back
up and create unity in the team after we
had essentially torn part of the team
apart so I stayed in close touch with
everyone we did a reset head team
meetings and I also worked real closely
with the other managers
company to make sure they were doing the
same with their direct employees it was
clear actually that our services were
still very compelling to our clients we
actually closed more POS in 2009 then we
did in any other year it's just that the
size of the POS were much smaller so we
found the right operating model to get
through the difficult times and I sure
wouldn't want to go through it again but
having done so we're leaner we're more
efficient and actually we're better
positioned to take advantage as the
market is on the uptick
